channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Row over Budget home loans plan
item.description: A political row has blown up over claims a Budget initiative aimed at helping people get on the housing ladder could be used for second home purchases.

item.title: Archbishop of Canterbury enthroned
item.description: The Most Reverend Justin Welby is enthroned as Archbishop of Canterbury, and says there is "every possible reason for optimism" about the future of the Christian faith.

item.title: Cyprus economy is 'on the brink'
item.description: Cyprus' largest bank warns the country's economy desperately requires European help, as political leaders scramble to raise funds to secure a bailout.

item.title: UK braced for snow and heavy rain
item.description: The "miserable March" weather is set to continue with intense rainfall and significant snowfall for Friday and into the weekend, forecasters say.

item.title: Duke of Kent suffers mild stroke
item.description: The Duke of Kent, the Queen's cousin, is treated at a London hospital after suffering a "mild stroke", Buckingham Palace says.

item.title: Scottish referendum date announced
item.description: The Scottish independence referendum will be held on 18 September, 2014, First Minister Alex Salmond announces.

item.title: Sarkozy placed under investigation
item.description: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy is placed under formal investigation over allegations he accepted illegal campaign donations in 2007.

item.title: Obama urges return to peace talks
item.description: Barack Obama urges Israelis and Palestinians to return to peace talks as he makes his first visit to Israel and the West Bank as US president.

item.title: Hackers attack BBC Twitter accounts
item.description: The BBC has become the latest victim of Twitter hackers as several of its feeds, including @bbcweather, are taken over by pro-Syrian hackers.

item.title: Syria cleric among mosque bomb dead
item.description: At least 42 people, including a leading pro-government cleric, are killed by a blast at a mosque in the Syrian capital, Damascus, say state media.

item.title: Supreme Court holds secret hearing
item.description: The UK's Supreme Court holds a hearing in secret for the first time in its history.

item.title: Clegg attacked by 'stay-at-home mum'
item.description: Nick Clegg is accused of unfairly targeting "stay-at-home mums" through the government's new childcare scheme by a caller to his radio-phone in show.

item.title: Branson urges curriculum changes
item.description: Business magnate Sir Richard Branson calls for changes to the national curriculum to encourage a spirit of enterprise and an understanding of business.

item.title: VIDEO: Faith leaders mark enthronement
item.description: Faith leaders are among the hundreds of people attending the Archbishop of Canterbury's enthronement on Thursday.

item.title: AUDIO: Scottish students debate right to vote
item.description: Students from The Mary Erskine School in Edinburgh discuss the issue of their knowledge of politics and the right to vote.

item.title: Politicians tackled over big issues
item.description: School Report asks high-profile politicians such as David Cameron and Boris Johnson to address issues as diverse as knife crime and Scottish independence.

item.title: West Ham players on tackling racism
item.description: West Ham footballers were quizzed by students at an Essex school as part of the School Report project.

item.title: VIDEO: Pupils 'concerned about unemployment'
item.description: The number of young people aged 16-24 without a job rose to 993,000 between November and January, taking the youth unemployment rate to 21.2%.

item.title: Voyager explores 'brand new region'
item.description: A student at Matthew Moss High School, Rochdale, interviewed Oxford University’s Dr Robert Simpson about Voyager's continued exploration of space beyond our solar system.

item.title: AUDIO: Students explore punk revival
item.description: Hove Park School near Brighton has been exploring whether the punk revival amongst teenagers means history is repeating itself...

item.title: Death row tale wins children's prize
item.description: Annabel Pitcher's Ketchup Clouds is named winner of this year's Waterstones Children's Book Prize.

item.title: YouTube reaches one billion users
item.description: YouTube, the video sharing site owned by Google, has announced it has passed one billion regular users.

item.title: Energy boss warns of blackout risk
item.description: The boss of the energy firm SSE warns that "there is a very real risk of the lights going out" in Britain.

item.title: Co-op Bank in £674m annual loss
item.description: The Co-operative Bank says it made a loss and will sell an insurance unit to rescue a deal to take over some of Lloyds Banking Group's branches.

item.title: Abbott war on 'sexual' billboards
item.description: Dianne Abbott calls for a purge of 'sexualised' imagery from UK High Streets - and blames online bullying of young women on a "crisis in masculinity".

item.title: Speaker 'concerned' over Budget leak
item.description: Speaker John Bercow says he is "concerned" that details of the Budget appeared on social media before being announced in the House of Commons.

item.title: 'Most GPs' have given placebo drugs
item.description: Most family doctors in Britain have prescribed a placebo or dummy drug to at least one of their patients, survey findings suggest.

item.title: Bed shortages 'harming patients'
item.description: Hospital bed and staff shortages across the West Midlands mean patients are suffering as ambulances cannot unload at A&E, a senior officer says.

item.title: Unis to compete for 'top 115,000'
item.description: Universities in England could be competing for more than 100,000 top students this autumn, the Higher Education Funding Council estimates.

item.title: Headlines and deadlines for School Report 2013
item.description: From punks to policemen, Boris to budgets, School Reporters covered a huge range of stories on the seventh annual News Day.

item.title: Internet scanned for security holes
item.description: A surreptitious scan of the entire internet reveals millions of printers, webcams and set-top boxes protected only by default passwords.

item.title: Google joins digital memo market
item.description: Google has launched Keep, an app aiming to help consumers create checklists and memos in digital form.

item.title: Stunning new view of 'oldest light'
item.description: A new map of the "oldest light" in the Universe provides new insights about both the origins and the composition of the cosmos.

item.title: Sunken Apollo rocket engines raised
item.description: A team recovers two F-1 rocket engines from Apollo-era rockets from the Atlantic seafloor, intending to restore them and put them on display.

item.title: Pink Floyd album saved for future
item.description: Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon is to seal its place in history at the US Library of Congress as part of its National Recording Registry.

item.title: Authors pay tribute to James Herbert
item.description: Fellow authors pay tribute to The Rats novelist James Herbert, who died on Wednesday aged 69.

item.title: 10 things about the enthronement
item.description: Justin Welby is to be enthroned as the 105th Archbishop of Canterbury at Canterbury Cathedral. Here are 10 lesser-known facts about the ceremony.

item.title: Should everybody get paid bereavement leave?
item.description: If a loved one dies, there are no guarantees that a worker will get paid bereavement leave. Should this be a legal right?

item.title: Dwyer 'in shock' over racing ban
item.description: Jockey Martin Dwyer will appeal after he is given a two-month ban by the Indian racing authorities.

item.title: Rose eclipses Woods in Florida
item.description: Justin Rose takes the early lead after a seven-under 65 on day one of the Arnold Palmer Invitational, as Tiger Woods shoots a 69.

item.title: Hodgson coy on Ferdinand future
item.description: England manager Roy Hodgson says he will "wait and see" whether he calls Rio Ferdinand into his squad again.

item.title: BBC expands county cricket coverage
item.description: The BBC will broadcast live commentary on every county game this summer under a new deal with the ECB.

item.title: Dyke appointment signals new beginning
item.description: Sports editor David Bond takes a look at the possible consequences of Greg Dyke's appointment as FA chairman.

item.title: Rain brings fresh floods to Cornwall
item.description: Flooding hits town in west Cornwall as heavy rain and surface water damages properties and makes roads hazardous.

item.title: Man arrested before enthronement
item.description: A man is arrested after allegedly running at a car carrying the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall at the Archbishop of Canterbury's enthronement

item.title: Renewed snow warning for Scotland
item.description: A renewed warning of snow across Scotland is issued, with many parts of the country facing fresh falls.

item.title: 'Wee Man' nets youngest Bafta win
item.description: A 12-year-old boy who played a young Paul Ferris in the film The Wee Man becomes the youngest ever winner of a new talent Bafta.

item.title: Laird defends links to Giants buyer
item.description: The Ulster Unionist peer Lord Laird was a paid advisor to a registered sex offender in Florida and hosted meetings for him at the House of Lords as part of a takeover of the Belfast Giants ice hockey team.

item.title: PSNI to fund future HET inquiries
item.description: The head of the team reviewing all Troubles killings has criticised a decision to hand over funding responsibility to the PSNI.

item.title: 'Fire alarm' over patient death rate
item.description: Eleven out of 17 district general hospitals in Wales have higher death rates than should be expected, according to official statistics.

item.title: Heavy snow and rain disruption alert
item.description: Forecasters warn that heavy snow and rain could cause disruption in parts of north and south Wales in coming days.

item.title: Gaddafi family 'not in Algeria'
item.description: Three of Col Muammar Gaddafi's children and his widow have left Algeria, its ambassador to Libya says.

item.title: Kagame backs 'Terminator' transfer
item.description: Rwanda's President Paul Kagame says he supports the speedy transfer of Congolese war crimes suspect Bosco Ntaganda to the International Criminal Court (ICC).

item.title: Italy to return marines to India
item.description: Two Italian marines accused of murdering two Indian fishermen, in a case that has sparked a diplomatic row, are to be sent back for trial.

item.title: UN criticises Sri Lanka on rights
item.description: The UN's Human Rights Council passes a resolution highly critical of Sri Lanka's record, pushing for a credible investigation into alleged war crimes.

item.title: Kurd rebel leader calls Turkey truce
item.description: Jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan calls a truce and urges his fighters to withdraw from Turkey after years of war - a move welcomed by Ankara.

item.title: Hungarian journalist returns prize
item.description: A Hungarian journalist accused of making anti-Semitic and anti-Roma remarks returns a government prize following an outcry.

item.title: Wave of prawn deaths baffles Chile
item.description: Authorities in Chile investigate the death of thousands of prawns and other shellfish that turned red a beach in Coronel, about 530km of Santiago.

item.title: US plays down Guantanamo protest
item.description: A senior US general plays down reports that more than 20 Guantanamo Bay inmates are on hunger strike, saying they are eating some food.

item.title: Saudi Shia leaders criticise arrests
item.description: A number of Shia community leaders in Saudi Arabia sign a statement condemning the recent arrest of 16 Shia citizens on allegations of spying.

item.title: Al-Qaeda claims Baghdad bombings
item.description: A militant umbrella group that includes al-Qaeda in Iraq says it was behind the wave of bombings in Baghdad on Tuesday which killed some 50 people.

item.title: Innocent 'rabbi killer' freed in NY
item.description: A New York judge frees a man unjustly convicted of murdering a rabbi 23 years ago, offering what she acknowledged was a "grossly inadequate" apology.

item.title: Drop in US hate crime reporting
item.description: Nearly two in three hate crimes in the US are not reported to police as victims doubt police can or will help, justice department statistics show.

item.title: In pictures: Obama in Israel
item.description: Obama's first visit to Israel as president

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 20 March

item.title: In pictures: Car bombs bring chaos to Baghdad
item.description: Aftermath of a series of explosions in Iraqi capital

item.title: In pictures: Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: Winners of the Open, 3D and Youth categories

item.title: In Pictures: The career of Frank Thornton
item.description: A look at the career of the Are You Being Served?

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 19 March

item.title: In pictures: India's Parsis
item.description: India's ancient Parsi community, on show in Mumbai

item.title: Day in pictures: 18 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 18 March

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The government defends its new mortgage guarantee scheme from Labour criticism.

item.title: VIDEO: Snow warning across much of UK
item.description: The Met office has warned of significant snow across much of the UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Which is better - the 1980s or today?
item.description: In a special film for BBC News School Report, Ola, Leila and Alice travel back to the decade of legwarmers, neon and Rubik's cubes and ask whether it was better to be a teenager in the 1980s or now.

item.title: VIDEO: Maps detail Universe's ancient light
item.description: A map tracing the "oldest light" in the sky has been produced by Europe's Planck Surveyor satellite.

item.title: AUDIO: Why do we invent monsters?
item.description: Why are there so many stories about monsters? From dragons to vampires and aliens, we have always told stories about scary mythical creatures.

item.title: VIDEO: Iraq doctors report birth defect rise
item.description: Doctors at the Basra maternity hospital in Iraq have told the BBC that they have seen a 60% rise in birth defects since 2003.

item.title: VIDEO: Mystery of Chile's crustacean carpet
item.description: Authorities in Chile are investigating why thousands of prawns were washed up on a beach in the coastal city of Coronel, covering it with a layer of pink.

item.title: VIDEO: Students give 'The Fonz' a dance lesson
item.description: School Reporters from Woolwich Polytechnic School in London have persuaded Henry Winkler, aka The Fonz, to dance the azonto with them.

item.title: VIDEO: 'How dare they take our babies'
item.description: As an official apology is issued to people affected by Australia's forced adoption policy between the 1950s and 1970s, some of the women who had their babies taken describe their pain.

item.title: Black Miss Israel will go to the ball
item.description: The black Miss Israel attending Barack Obama's gala dinner

item.title: The locust-eaters of Israel
item.description: Locusts are invading your country - do you eat them?

item.title: Teenagers and their sleepless lives
item.description: Teenagers on their social media and technology habits

item.title: Twitter celebrates seventh birthday
item.description: What some of its 200m users make of Twitter, as it turns seven

item.title: Reconsidering the two-state solution
item.description: Israelis and Palestinians consider one- and three-state solutions

item.title: Australia's coup culture
item.description: Why Australia dumps leaders like football managers

item.title: BBC School Report: Zoomable mosaic of your images
item.description: Giant image made up of hundreds of your pictures

item.title: How the Taliban gripped Karachi
item.description: How the Taliban are taking hold of Pakistan's main city

item.title: President Obama gives peace a chance
item.description: President Obama gives peace a chance

item.title: The life of (Raspberry) Pi
item.description: Clever ideas with a tiny computer
